body:
Here's some background info from my blog:

http://datasieve.blogspot.com/2013/07/directbytebuffer-in-java.html

@squito AFAIK code improvements are only accepted in a form of [jira ticket + attached patch file](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA). Not absolutely sure what is the official policy, but looks like this mirror is kept only for code navigation/personal forks purpose.
thanks @lazyval .  I've created this ticket https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-1144 .

Since kafka is now an apache project, you have to fill [JIRA issue](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA) and attach [patch](https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/12.patch) to it. PRs are not accepted as far as I know (which is a sad fact by the way).

see also https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/10

Apache Kafka has an open source patch review tool https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Kafka+patch+review+tool that works with JIRA and Reviewboard.  File a JIRA first maybe send something on the dev list or pick a JIRA label to try out and contrib a patch.

Could you open an Apache Kafka jira and attach the patch there? This will take care of Apache licensing issues.

Thanks,

Jun

There is currently a caveat with this system, which is that if you co-host brokers on the same physical node, having a max-rack-replication > 1 can result in 2 or more replicas ending up on the same physical node. This is easy to fix as the hostname is already available, and I can add it if this gets traction.

Could you open an Apache Kafka jira and attach the patch there? This will take care of Apache licensing issues.

Thanks,

Jun
KAFKA-1226 added

Done.  I created this JIRA
tickethttps://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-1230for it.
Please advise if this is enough or would you like to get the patch
sent via some other means.
Best,

Thanks for the patch. Committed to trunk.

I think this shouldn't happen because we are using Log.deleteOldSegments which should delete from old to new until there is a segment which doesn't need deleting when it stops. In other words that pre-condition is enforced in the application of the method. Are you able to reproduce a problem?

I run this command

``` js
bin/kafka-console-producer.sh --broker-list localhost:9092 --topic topic1 --compression-codec 1
```

But it seems not work, the message attribute is always 0.

No, you have to specify the codec name, either snappy or gzip

bin/kafka-console-producer.sh --broker-list localhost:9092 --topic topic1 --compress --compression-codec snappy

It seems kafka.logs.dir  is just local variable for local reference.

> It seems kafka.logs.dir is just local variable for local reference.

It isn't though. Try changing its value. You will see that nothing actually changes i.e. the value of the kafka.logs.dir system property is used instead. So having it there is highly misleading (I was bitten by this).

A little bit more information: according to http://logging.apache.org/log4j/1.2/apidocs/org/apache/log4j/PropertyConfigurator.html the property is first searched in the system properties, and then only if the system property does not exist, then in the local file (which is weird, I would have implemented it in the reverse search order, to allow a system default with a local override).

Since `kafka.logs.dir` is always created as a system property by the start script, the local property in log4j.properties is never used.
Thanks for the explanation. Could you create a Kafka jira and attach a patch there? This will take care of the Apache licensing stuff.
Done: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-1801

Joshua, 

The Kafka team uses review board for patch submissions as explained here https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Patch+submission+and+review. You might want to submit this change as explained in there.

Thanks for letting me know.  That process looks too involved for my minor fixes, but if I make more substantial contributions in the future, I will get myself setup to use the Kafka patch submission process.

@redbaron Kafka tracks issues & patches in [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA/) and has a [patch review tool](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Kafka+patch+review+tool) for code review. Could you submit this over there?

```

            org.apache.kafka.common.requests.OffsetCommitRequest.DEFAULT_TIMESTAMP
                                                                 ^

                             commitTimestamp: Long = org.apache.kafka.common.requests.OffsetCommitRequest.DEFAULT_TIMESTAMP,
                                                                                                          ^
/Users/nnarkhed/Projects/kafka/core/src/main/scala/kafka/common/OffsetMetadataAndError.scala:35: value DEFAULT_TIMESTAMP in object OffsetCommitRequest is deprecated: see corresponding Javadoc for more information.
                             expireTimestamp: Long = org.apache.kafka.common.requests.OffsetCommitRequest.DEFAULT_TIMESTAMP) {
                                                                                                          ^
/Users/nnarkhed/Projects/kafka/core/src/main/scala/kafka/server/KafkaApis.scala:187: value DEFAULT_TIMESTAMP in object OffsetCommitRequest is deprecated: see corresponding Javadoc for more information.

                                                                                                        ^
/Users/nnarkhed/Projects/kafka/core/src/main/scala/kafka/server/KafkaServer.scala:216: a pure expression does nothing in statement position; you may be omitting necessary parentheses
    ControllerStats.uncleanLeaderElectionRate
                    ^
/Users/nnarkhed/Projects/kafka/core/src/main/scala/kafka/server/KafkaServer.scala:217: a pure expression does nothing in statement position; you may be omitting necessary parentheses
    ControllerStats.leaderElectionTimer
                    ^
/Users/nnarkhed/Projects/kafka/core/src/main/scala/kafka/server/OffsetManager.scala:391: value DEFAULT_TIMESTAMP in object OffsetCommitRequest is deprecated: see corresponding Javadoc for more information.
                      if (value.expireTimestamp == org.apache.kafka.common.requests.OffsetCommitRequest.DEFAULT_TIMESTAMP)
```

Other than that, it looks good.

@nehanarkhede, there are indeed two warnings ("a pure expression does nothing in a statement position"). The original patch fixed these by removing two calls in `KafkaServer.registerStats`. That change would mean that the metrics would not be registered during start-up anymore. They would, instead, be registered on first access to `ControllerStats`. Is this acceptable? Since I wasn't sure, I removed that change from this PR. I think changing that code should probably be done as part of a separate issue as it may involve some refactoring (the way metrics registration happens as a side-effect of triggering object initialisation is not great, in my opinion).

The other warnings are related to deprecations and should also be tackled separately.
Thanks @nehanarkhede Applied your review comments at #58 Closing this.Thanks

bq. I think changing that code should probably be done as part of a separate issue as it may involve some refactoring (the way metrics registration happens as a side-effect of triggering object initialisation is not great, in my opinion).

@ijuma Makes sense. I will merge this PR.

should i squash commits right now ?

Not sure about squashing commits, using Github PRs is new for Kafka. I _think_ that happens as part of the commit process, which is not managed through Github. You'll need a committer to approve this anyway, I'm just reviewing since I helped with the Vagrantfile previously. I think @nehanarkhede was shepherding the new Github PR approach and might know the process better.

Looks like you committed a lot of files that shouldn't have been committed at all. Everything under core/data.

Can you clean it up a bit?
Also, was the change to gradle file intentional?
Closing this pull request and created https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/64 for KAFKA-2167.
any news ?

Probably worth clarifying that before this gets committed we'll want one final update to pin ducktape to a specific version, but there's no need push that ducktape release to PyPI until we're sure we have all the changes to ducktape we need to land this patch. We don't normally want people to have to checkout ducktape from its repository in order to run the system tests.

As Ewen mentioned, I won't pin these changes to a ducktape release until just before merging in case updates to ducktape are requested while this pull request is being examined.

To clarify what changes are present in this pull request: This initial pull request contains a small number of tests which starts but does not complete the process of porting/replacing existing system test code (https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Roadmap+-+port+existing+system+tests) It also has updates to Vagrant necessary for running the tests on a Vagrant cluster.

Kafka codebase:
- New tool called VerifiableProducer which writes metadata about produce requests to stdout
- corresponding update to build.gradle
- Other small refactorings

Vagrant:
- Updates to Vagrantfile and some examples of Vagrantfile.local which are necessary for running the tests with ducktape

tests/ directory:
- This contains the python code which makes up the actual sample system tests as well as a few core Service classes (e.g. Zookeeper, Kafka, ConsoleConsumer etc.)

FYI: git clone git@github.com:confluentinc/ducktape.git 
doesn't work for everyone. git clone https://github.com/confluentinc/ducktape.git
does.
